qas.question: What usually covers the whole trunk of a very young tree?
What evidence of the stubs of the limbs a tree loses can always be seen in the wood?
In a very old tree, are you more likely to find a lot of knots in the heartwood or the sapwood?
What hides the stubs of a tree's lost limbs from being visible later in its life?
Since knots are defects that weaken lumber, would the heartwood or the sapwood from the same tree be stronger?

context: When a tree is very young it is covered with <a0_0>limbs<a0_0/> almost, if not entirely, to the ground, but as it grows older some or all of them will eventually die and are either broken off or fall off. <a3_0>Subsequent growth<a3_0/> of wood may completely conceal the stubs which will however remain as <a1_0>knots<a1_0/>. No matter how smooth and clear a log is on the outside, it is more or less knotty near the middle. Consequently, the sapwood of an old tree, and particularly of a forest-grown tree, will be freer from knots than the inner <a2_0>heartwood<a2_0/>. Since in most uses of wood, knots are defects that weaken the timber and interfere with its ease of working and other properties, it follows that a given piece of <a4_0>sapwood<a4_0/>, because of its position in the tree, may well be stronger than a piece of heartwood from the same tree.
